llm_processed_output.source_summary: This text from the Encyclopédie berbère provides a historical overview of the Zawiya of Dila' from its founding in 1566 by ššix Abu Bakr ben Muḥammad El Mejjati Es-Ṣanḥaji (1536-1612) until its decline and eventual destruction in 1668. It details the Zawiya's initial role as a religious center and its gradual expansion into a political and military power under Muḥammad ElḤajj. The text highlights the Zawiya's relationships with various Berber tribes, its economic activities through Saharan trade, its conflicts with the Sa'adian and Alawite dynasties, and the reasons for its eventual downfall. The Alawite Mulay Rashid defeated the Dila'ites in 1668 at Bothen-Er-Romman and destroyed the Zawiya of Dila'. A final attempt to revive the Dila'ite cause was made in 1677 by Aḥamad ben ‘Abdallah, but it failed.
extracted_key_facts: The Zawiya of Dila' was founded around 1566 by ššix Abu Bakr ben Muḥammad El Mejjati Es-Ṣanḥaji (1536-1612) in central Morocco.
The Zawiya's initial location was near the qṣur of M‘ammar, 10 kilometers southeast of Ayt Isḥaq, later a more important zawiya was built in Ayt Ishaq itself.
Dila' emerged as a spiritual and temporal center of a Berber state, representing an attempt at Ṣenḥaja restoration.
The Zawiya of Dila' was initially supported by the Sa'adian rulers.
The marabouts of Dila' gained influence through religious prestige, generosity, and resolving disputes among transhumant Amazigh pastors in the Middle Atlas.
The Ayt Idrassen confederation, including the Mejjat, Ayt Nḍir, Ayt Sadden, Ayt ‘Ayyaš, Ayt Yummur, Ayt Wallal, Ayt Wafella, and Imelwan tribes, were within the Zawiya's sphere of influence.
Initially, the Zawiya focused on Quranic teaching, conflict resolution, and hospitality.
The Zawiya's influence extended beyond the Middle Atlas, encompassing the entire Amazigh country, including the High Moulouya and the eastern High Atlas.
The Zawiya established links with the qṣar of Tabu‘asamt in Tafilalt to facilitate trade between Saharan people and mountain dwellers.
The zawiyas of Sidi Hamza and Sidi Bu Ya‘qub became relays of Dila'ite influence.
The Ayt Yafelman alliance was created around 1630 under Dila'ite influence to counter Semlalite expansionism.
In 1645/46, Zawit Aḥanṣal was associated with the Dila'ite movement.
Muḥammad ElḤajj aimed for temporal power, leading to the creation of a solid base and an army.
A second zawiya was created on the site of Zawiya des Ayt Ishaq, along with a fortified city.
In 1638, Muḥammad ElḤajj confronted and defeated the Sa'adian power near the Oued L‘abid.
In 1641, Dila'ite troops occupied Salé, ousting El ‘Ayyaši, and controlled the lucrative commerce of the coastal city for nearly two decades.
In 1646, Muḥammad ElḤajj won the battle of Lgara against the Alawites.
Following the victory against the Alawites in 1646, the Dilaïtes entered Tafilalt.
A pact designated the Jbel El ‘Ayyaši as the border between Dila'ite and Alawite influence zones, with Dila' gaining five strategic fortresses.
By 1659, Muḥammad Elḥajj was named sultan in Fes.
In 1661, the province north seceded under Ghailan, and Salé was lost, weakening the Dila'ite power.
In 1663, the Dila'ites abandoned Fes as their capital, with Muḥammad ElḤajj ruling from the Zawiya of Dila'.
Between 1664 and 1666, the Alawites unified under Mulay Rašid, taking Meknes and Fes.
In 1668, Mulay Rašid defeated the Dila'ites at Bothen-Er-Romman and destroyed the Zawiya of Dila' in M'ammar.
In 1677, Aḥamad ben ‘Abdallah, grandson of Muḥammad ElḤajj, attempted to revive the Dila'ite cause with Turkish support, but failed.
